body: @fjy rebased, should pass travis now
@binlijin can you squash commits?

IMO the importance of the issues @dclim raised are, from most important to least,
- 3 (supervisor persisting) is critical
- 6 (avoiding killing "safe" tasks on startup) is important to make people feel like it's safe to restart overlords whenever they want (which is currently the case, and we want to keep it that way)
- 2 (unnecessary replicas being killed and FAILED) is important, as the current behavior will be confusing for users like @himanshug pointed out
- 1 (eliminating ingestion pauses) is going to be critical for users that have a real real-time requirement, and nice to have for other users
- 5 (early stopping) would be nice for getting schema updates out faster. Kafka tasks support restoreTasksOnRestart so I think this is not really needed for rolling updates (the tasks can restore after a MM restart)
- 4 (keeping replicas in sync) is nice but least important

Of those I think 3, 6, 2 are important to do before releasing the feature at all.

I think we can live without 1 for the first release but should do it in a follow-up.

I think 5, 4 are nice improvements but less critical than the others.

@himanshug - does this sound reasonable to you?

The same with `/druid/coordinator/v1/datasources/{dataSourceName}/intervals/{interval}`
where I assume that `/` should be substituted with `_`

I think @gianm already explained well (thanks!) on the intention of this patch. Current serde for inputRow is making very big complex binary and seemed not possible to use binary combiner (forgot the exact name of this in hadoop). Then for combining rows hadoop must read object form binary and write it again, which is big work for both cpu and memory.
@xvrl Could I understand that as this would be better in druid, not in java-util?
@du00cs any chance of squashing commits?

@nishantmonu51 #2571 is for using hash map rather than treemap in incremental index. This is for sorting aggregated result (from incremental index) only in the final stage. Similar but different patch.

@l15k4 Once you disable a segment it takes a while for coordinator to update it's view of "used" segments depending on `druid.coordinator.period` and `druid.manager.segments.pollDuration` both of which by default is set to a minute. In worst scenario it can take up to `druid.coordinator.period + druid.manager.segments.pollDuration` for changes to reflect. Do you still see the segment after a while ?

@himanshug I need know target segments and locations from predicates (or sarg) made in hive. `DataSourceInputFormat` is a good start point but still need this PR to cover our use case.

Why the old version will use CompressedVSizeIntsIndexedWriter in UNCOMPRESSED configuration?
If you configured "uncompressed", the IndexSpec will return null when we call getDimensionCompressionStrategy().
And if dimCompression is null, IndexMergerV9 will return either VSizeIndexedWriter or VSizeIndexedIntsWriter depends on whether is multi-value dimension

Though there is https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2650  for the hadoop batch indexing test, I suggest leaving this issue open to keep track of what would be needed if we ever modify things so when we use docker for testing, docker can do hadoop.  

https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2650 includes the code changes needed for running the hadoop test with docker.  Those changes are:
  in pom.xml, a line in the configuration for integration-tests setting druid.tes.config.hadoopDir
  in DockerConfigProvider, be able to getProperty("hadoopTestDir")

All that would be needed once docker can do hadoop is an edit to integration-tests/README.md to say to export HADOOP_DIR to the name of a directory containing batchHadoop1, where the test data is in hdfs.

@gianm from https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2656#issuecomment-197656072 , i believe that (6) is already done.
I agree with 3,6,2 being important.

(4) would be nice to have but very hard to do without adding complexity , not having it is fine. also, (1) is not too critical at least for now in the first cut.

currently user is required to set "the number of events each task should handle before persisting a segment and completing" . it will be very convenient if this is dynamically figured out by the system automatically. I thought (5) could probably help support this too in addition to speeding up schema updates as you pointed.
@fjy I :+1: on @gianm suggestion apart from that I do not have any more comments

@himanshug thanks for your feedback - what were you thinking of as an alternative to having the user specify the number of events a task will handle? It might be interesting if we allowed the user to specify a target for how long they want the task to run and then run an initial task to ingest a small number of events to get a feel of the events/sec and then use this to tune our offset ranges. Also like you said, if we had graceful shutdown we could guarantee tasks live as long as we want them to. Is that along the lines of what you were thinking? (have the user set the lifetime of the task in time vs number of events)

@dclim as discussed on dev sync it will be nice if supervisor starts the tasks with some very large arbitrary end-offset and then forces the push if/when segments reach some size threshold or some time (e.g. 30 mins) has elasped.
@l15k4 Oh I see...I think it is a known bug in case all the segments on the cluster are disabled, the last last one remains, see this - https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1274

this change was discussed during the dev sync on 2016-03-22 as a way of clarifying which configs are from extensions and which configs are not.

@himanshug i think this doesn't work if `errorBoundsStdDev` is set (as that makes the post aggregator return `SketchEstimateWithErrorBounds` which has no natural ordering).

it sounds ok to me to use a comparator that works off the `estimate` in that object, although because that is not consistent with equals, it may be better for that to be a separate Comparator instance rather than the natural ordering.

@navis 

re: changing SelectorFilter and JavascriptFilter to implement DimensionPredicateFilter

There are some performance considerations if that change were made:
- getBitmapIndex() for DimensionPredicateFilter requires a scan through the column's dictionary values to determine which values matched the predicate. For SelectorFilter without an extraction function, the current getBitmapIndex() is much simpler/faster since it can just call selector.getBitmapIndex(dimension, value).
- For JavascriptFilter, the current implementation allows getBitmapIndex() to reuse the Context object across the scan of the dictionary. Using the JavascriptPredicate with DimensionPredicateFilter's getBitmapIndex() function would result in a new Context object being created on every apply() call. There's a note regarding this performance consideration at:
  https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/processing/src/main/java/io/druid/segment/filter/JavaScriptFilter.java#L92

I think, if that change is desirable, it's better handled in a separate PR.

@navis you can close and re-open to get tests to re-run if the failure is not related.
@navis looks good, could you please include docs too though?

The approach here looks good.

I would like to see more unit tests covering the new code.

There are some field additions which are added to hashCode and equals, and some which are not. I assume the later is because the classes lack hachCode and equals. Sometimes hashCode and equals are just used in unit tests, which is fine, but such a use should probably be called out in a javadoc in the class for clarification. Fixing hashCode and equals for classes that are missing it is probably outside the scope of this PR, but filing an issue with the offending classes (if indeed hashCode and equals are improperly missing) would be helpful.

We have been holding back on jackson upgrades due to issues with Hadoop. Jackson version conflicts seem to cause so many problems, maybe we should publish an io.druid jackson that is relocated and just use that…

:+1: after travis. @gianm would you mind making a notification on the druid-api readme that the former repository is deprecated as of 0.9.1, and any patches should be submitted against this repository?
